messageBody:
Chappell, Simon P wrote:

> J.B.
>
> Interesting. What naming convention would you use?
>
> testIndexOf1()
> testIndexOf2()
> etc

I wouldn't number them, that's for sure. :)

If they are just tests of the same method invocation, but with different
data, then I would put them in their own Parameterized Test Suite. (This
is a technique for which I have just developed particular support, so
don't worry about it for now.)

If there is just one test for each row of data, then you can use the
Parameterized Test Case pattern.

class IndexOfTest extends TestCase...
constructor(testName, string, pattern, expectedIndex)
super(testName)
// store the rest in fixture variables

runTest
assertEquals(expectedIndex, string.indexOf(pattern))

suite
suite = new TestSuite("IndexOf tests")
suite.add(new IndexOfTest("pattern == string", "hello", "hello", 0));
suite.add(new IndexOfTest("pattern is initial substring", "hello",
"hel", 0));
suite.add(new IndexOfTest("pattern is medial substring", "hello",
"llo", 2));
...
return suite

I would write one of these for each different String method, then
perhaps a StringSuite that collects them all.

> And, by one assertion, I hope you don't mean a maximum of one physical
> "assertEquals"!?

No; that's exactly what I mean. See either the TDD or XP list for
details. (You may prefer just to buy Dave Astels a drink one night.)
